repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Emergency Economic Recovery
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Economic Recovery Credit
            for Bolivia had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was negligible, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that it was clear from the outset
            that the use of the Emergency Recovery Loan instrument was
            to pose challenges both internally (at the Board) and with
            the client (in terms of providing fast disbursement) given
            that the instrument was not designed to provide fast
            disbursing liquidity transfers. Based on the shortcomings of
            this experience, OPCS has now devised a new policy, under
            the new Development Policy Lending guidelines, to address
            crisis and post conflict situations where there may not be
            sufficient time or country capacity to adequately address
            design considerations or a strong policy program developed
            with stakeholder consultation. It has now been established
            by OPCS that in such situations, development policy lending
            (rather than investment lending as was used in this case) is
            justified on an exceptional basis.

5087124.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
In line with the upcoming Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS) objectives - strengthen
            governance, accelerate efforts to reduce inequality and
            exclusion, support macroeconomic stability - this Emergency
            Economic Recovery Project, structured as an emergency
            recovery operation in recognition of the crisis nature of
            the long-standing socioeconomic tensions that have led to
            frequent episodes of civil unrest, will provide support to
            the poor and vulnerable, by making available external funds
            for critical foreign goods (whether or not directly imported
            by the Government), including medicines, agricultural
            machinery (tractors), and diesel oil/gasoline. Quick
            disbursing financing will be provided for critical goods for
            reconstruction, economic recovery and mitigation of the
            social crisis, and for financial management, consistent with
            the emergency nature of this operation, these arrangements
            have been simplified and streamlined to the extent feasible.
            However, risks remain, above all, the presence of radical
            elements among the union-indigenous movement opposed to the
            current political environment, and, the unsure political
            power to ensure new legislation. In addition, civil service
            capacity constraints may undermine implementation of new
            policies, and, the gas referendum may prove difficult to implement.
